p: Secondary bacterial infection is a major cause of the mortality and morbidity associated with the influenza virus [ 1]. Bacterial pneumonia caused millions of deaths during influenza epidemics in the 20 th century [ 2]. For example, 94% of a group of patients who died in the 1918 influenza pandemic had evidence of secondary bacterial pneumonia [ 3], while 28% of fatalities in New York associated with the 2009 H1N1 influenza pandemic had bacterial co-infections, with most diagnosed post-mortem [ 4].
